stream_context.summary: Kaze builds the underground section of Course 11’s oil-rig level, finalising routes for the last star and Yoshi coins, choosing textures, placing an 8-bit pipe, and testing new crate and grate geometry while chatting with the team and viewers.

development_findings.summary: Only two sub-areas were still missing in Course 11; Kaze mapped entrances and objectives so the level now supports the final star and remaining Yoshi coins.
Underground layout: three surface entrances connect to a central space; one coin is earned by cleaning an oil patch with a Koopa shell, the other via a slide into a crevice.
development_findings.quote: One Yoshi coin is going to be cleaning up another oil spot right here with a shell … the other one is gonna be sliding down the slide and jumping into this crevice.

development_findings.summary: A large glass window (re-using an existing glass material) will let players look out from the power-plant interior to the watery exterior of the rig.
development_findings.quote: What if all of this was like the reinforced window … this is just gonna be transparent material.

development_findings.summary: Decision to hard-code most behaviours instead of using per-object parameters because exotic behaviours are rare and 255 slots are available.
development_findings.quote: I’d rather just have one parameter open … I can hard-code because it is so rare that I want a special behaviour like that.

development_findings.summary: New foot-surface sound system by Yoshi Milkman adds distinct audio sets for wood, steel, glass, leaves, squishy surfaces, and metal grates.
development_findings.quote: Listen closely … this is the new wood … metal grates … he put a lot of work into making this perfect.

development_findings.summary: Compression strategy: decompression now replaces Mario 64’s original 16-frame load delay; Kaze waits 8 frames so total load time feels identical while allowing larger assets.
development_findings.quote: Mario 64's loading times are so fast that they put an artificial 16-frame delay … we decompress … and instead of waiting 16 frames, we just wait 8.

development_findings.summary: Guidelines for freelance asset makers: keep geometry under ~150 polygons and use single 64×64 textures; Kaze will down-sample to N64 formats and supply the rig when bones are required.
development_findings.quote: The geometry … should be around less than 150 polygons … we’re limited to 64×64 textures … let me downscale it.

development_findings.summary: Planned new enemy: an oil version of the Frizzlet ghost that pools into a round puddle and damages the player; Kaze is seeking a modeller.
development_findings.quote: I want something like that, but made out of oil … it’s gonna damage you if you walk into it. That’s a random asset I need.

development_findings.summary: Optimization work has broadened artistic scope; Kaze will make a video framing these optimisations as the enabler for bringing more artists onto the project.
development_findings.quote: With all this optimization artists have so much more freedom and we brought more artists on board … it’s gonna be the angle.

development_findings.summary: Experimenting with a flame-buffer blur effect for a potential high-speed side level; undecided if N64 can handle it smoothly.
development_findings.quote: We should use this effect somewhere … unfortunately it doesn’t really go behind Mario … it won’t really work for a super speed level.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is sensitive to criticism about difficulty; he now intentionally makes levels easier, though Course 11 retains some advanced jumps.
context_findings.quote: When you make a rom-hack the criticism is always it’s too difficult, so I’ve been trying to make my games easier and easier.

context_findings.summary: He views technical optimisation as a path to artistic freedom and larger collaboration.
Personal move from Germany to Canada driven partly by lower taxes; expresses reluctance toward tipping and high tax rates.
context_findings.quote: I’m glad I moved to Canada instead of staying in Germany. I would be taxed so much money.

context_findings.summary: Channel growth motivates him; every new YouTube upload is outperforming the last.
context_findings.quote: Every video is doing better than the previous one—that’s actually crazy.

context_findings.summary: Shows philosophical, often humorous, interest in game-theory dilemmas and moral trade-offs (e.g., hostage and tipping analogies).

biobak.summary: Gives ongoing feedback on underground textures and props; will refine materials and ‘justify it in post.’
biobak.quote: I’ll definitely put this in for now … I’ll leave the exact details to you but I’ll definitely put this in for now.

badub.summary: Composed the ‘Buzzer 2’ track and is writing music for the upcoming oil boss cut-scene.
badub.quote: Yes actually, Badub made a song for it … and he’s already also making a song for the oil boss that’s like this.

zeina.summary: Joins chat to discuss animation tasks (e.g., monkey animations) and handles some real-life logistics (ordering fish) while collaborating on level ideas.

key_stories.title: Finishing Course 11 Underground
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed two final sub-areas to complete Course 11. He plotted three entrances, placed a slide route, shell-cleaning challenge, and an 8-bit pipe, selecting glass and grate textures to define the space.
key_stories.challenge: Level lacked the last star path and two Yoshi coins.
key_stories.process: Mapped entrances, decided coin mechanics, experimented with textures, adjusted platform difficulty.
key_stories.outcome: Functional underground layout ready for polishing; clear tasks for art pass and enemy placement.
key_stories.key_quote: Let me explain to you what this area is gonna be … the underground area is what we’re gonna be working on today.

key_stories.title: Revamping Footstep Audio
key_stories.summary: Immersion was limited by generic footstep sounds. Yoshi Milkman delivered a custom surface-sound set, and Kaze demonstrated each material live.
key_stories.challenge: Default audio failed to convey varied materials.
key_stories.process: Collaborator recorded and integrated new samples; Kaze wired them to surface IDs.
key_stories.outcome: Distinct audio feedback for wood, steel, glass, leaves, squish, and grates now in-game.
key_stories.key_quote: He put a lot of work into making this perfect.

key_stories.title: Optimisation Enables Art
key_stories.summary: Kaze drafts a YouTube video framing recent engine optimisations as the reason more artists (e.g., Biobak) can now contribute higher-fidelity assets without harming performance.
key_stories.challenge: Need a compelling narrative for next promotional video.
key_stories.process: Identified optimisation achievements, linked them to expanded art pipeline.
key_stories.outcome: Video concept locked; will serve as both devlog and recruitment tool.
key_stories.key_quote: Look, with all this optimisation artists have so much more freedom…

open_questions.context: Kaze references numerous performance gains but gives no technical specifics.
questions: What were the key optimisations and who implemented them?
How do they translate to tangible artistic freedom?

open_questions.context: Kaze described desired behaviour and asked for a modeller.
questions: What finalized design and mechanics were chosen?
How will oil puddles be rendered and animated on N64 hardware?
Timeline and responsibilities for modelling, rigging, coding?

open_questions.context: Yoshi Milkman’s footstep overhaul is in but details are light.
questions: Any plans for dynamic mixing or per-character variations?
How were the samples recorded and processed?

open_questions.context: Kaze tested a motion-blur effect for a ‘super speed’ side level but doubts N64 viability.
questions: What technical hurdles remain for the blur effect?

open_questions.context: Current scheme uses custom decompression; XZ was mentioned but unprofiled.
questions: Will alternative algorithms like XZ be adopted?
How does decompression affect level streaming and memory budgets?
Any loading-time targets for final release?

open_questions.context: Kaze mused about porting Sunshine’s hub to N64 as a tech flex.
questions: Is this a serious goal or a tongue-in-cheek idea?
What would be required to make it run on real hardware?
